title: Friday, 16th December, 2016
bodyHTML:

11:10 am
PM11:10am

BE11:10am

Because several regulators, seemingly independently of each other, decided that betting on quasi-financial stuff is ... well ... betting.

PM11:10am

Reality dawns

11:10 am
PM11:10am

wow

BE11:11am

I mention this because today we have Shore knife-catching CMC.

BE11:11am

Which is now a contender for worst float in recent memory, though it is of course an extremely crowded field.

11:11 am
CMC Markets PLC (CMCX:LSE): Last: 111.20, up 9.2 (+9.02%), High: 111.66, Low: 105.30, Volume: 373.70k
PM11:12am

9% on a Shore recommendation

PM11:12am

This thing is down two thirds this year

11:12 am
BE11:12am

Paul McGinnis is your analyst here.

BE11:12am

Following last week's unexpected FCA consultation into the retail contract for difference (CFD) market, CMC Markets' shares have almost halved in value. We view what appears to be a co-ordinated tightening by several European regulators as a necessary action to protect inexperienced consumers from heavy losses trading a complex product. While we don't believe operators with more experienced, higher revenue clients like CMC were the prime focus of regulators, we think the proposals will impact the business. While forecasting the financial impact with an acceptable degree of accuracy is currently difficult, our view is that CMC shares offer an attractive margin for error.

BE11:13am

Let me spin on a bit .....

11:13 am
BE11:13am

The FCA consultation observes that client losses in jurisdictions with leverage limits are 20-40% lower than in jurisdictions without leverage limits (based on comparing a sample against a jurisdiction which has leverage limits similar to those being proposed by the FCA). It is unclear whether this data compared to losses in a specific period or lifetime losses (i.e. it may not take account of the lower churn point made above).

BE11:14am

Attempting to forecast the outcome is extremely difficult at present and may not get much easier even when the consultation finishes and the mandated rules come into force (mid 2017). This will make budgeting a very tricky exercise for CMC. We have tried to be conservative in our revised financial forecasts but would issue a major health warning that these numbers could be subject to very material revision over the next twelve months. We have tried to pitch them such that we think that the probability of revision is more likely to be positive but clearly there can be no certainty that this will be the case.

BE11:14am

(@Lemmy: I suggest it's exactly as hard as I make it look.)

11:14 am
BE11:14am

We have reduced assumptions for both active customers and average revenue per customer, with the largest revision applied to the UK business. Some of this is mitigated by cost cuts, focused on marketing and employee costs. In summary, our Net Operating Income (revenue) forecast falls by 22% in y/e Mar ’18 and 29% for Mar ’19. At the earnings per share level, after some cost mitigation, this results in adjusted eps down 34% for Mar 18 and 44% for Mar ’19. As noted above we would hope that there will be scope to upgrade these numbers as the picture becomes clearer.

BE11:14am

We have previously set our fair value for CMC based on a 15% discount to the rating we apply to competitor IG
Group^ (IGG, Hold [from Sell] at 480p) on the basis of CMC’s weaker operational performance in 2016. This
equated to a forward PE multiple 12.75x and we think it would be dangerous to now apply an even lower rating to
heavily downgraded earnings, particularly as any short term earnings hit may be overstating the loss of lifetime
value as explained above. We therefore apply a 12x multiple to our downgraded Mar 18 eps of 12.4p resulting in a revised fair value of 150p (down from 215p). With upside of 50%, we think this gives investors a sufficiently wide margin of error for us to upgrade from Hold to BUY, accepting that the risks involved are high and not easily quantifiable at stage.

BE11:14am

You get the idea there.

11:14 am
PM11:14am

I'm sure you've done this to death last week, but my, this makes me angry -- FCA finally waking up to the need for leverage caps. I mean I have literally been writing about this for 6/7 years.

BE11:15am

Yep, there was a lot of sellside saying the leverage limits proposal came out of leftfield.

BE11:15am

What universe do these people exist? Seriously?

11:16 am
PM11:16am

You know how the FCA routinely refuses FOI requests

BE11:16am

Indeed I do.

PM11:16am

Well, I wonder whether they could refuse to name the officials heading oversight of this sector over the past decade?

11:16 am
BE11:16am

Hm.

PM11:17am

Let's try it

BE11:18am

We should note that they claim to accept FOIs. Though I've never seen a single one on anything meaningful not just get the boilerplate rejection: https://www.fca.or...om-information-act

11:20 am

BE11:21am

Anyway, here's the recap of the CFD from last week. https://ftalphavil...tslive/2016-12-06/ ... We should perhaps move onto other stuff.

PM11:21am

BE11:22am

There's that, yes. And the dollar's gone vertical.

11:22 am
BE11:22am

As has gold, but the other kind of vertical.

PM11:22am

hehe

PM11:22am

$ move extraordinary

11:22 am
PM11:22am

The rate move was supposed to be in the price

BE11:23am

Which seems as good a reason as any to chuck up some 2017 prognosti-bumf.

BE11:24am

Credit Suisse has put its next-year theorising into a 110 slide presentation.

11:24 am
BE11:24am

I've read the first one, so fairly sure I have a good grasp of it.

PM11:25am

hehehe

BE11:25am

As we enter 2017, we asked each analyst to provide (1) investment themes that they see driving their sector next year and (2) the stocks they think will Outperform/Underperform. In addition, we incorporate the top down views from our economist and equity strategists.
Our Economics team expects the current rebound in US growth to continue into 2017 driving growth back into the low-2% range. In their view, a rebound in commodity prices is likely to boost headline inflation. They expect the Fed to hike twice in 2017, at the June and December meetings.
Our Global Equity Strategist is relatively more constructive on H1 than H2 2017. The team has set mid-year target for the S&P500 at 2,350 but they expect it fall to 2,300 given multiple headwinds in H2.
Our US Equity Strategist believes many of the post Trump trades have room to run. The team prefers Small Caps over Large and Value over Growth heading into 2017. With respect to sectors, the team is Overweight on all three Financials industry groups (Banks, Diversified Financials, Insurance) as well as Consumer Durables & Apparel given attractive valuation and less interest rate risk vs. Consumer Services. They are Underweight bond proxies that look expensive (Utilities, Food Beverage & Tobacco, and Food & Staples Retail).

11:25 am
PM11:25am

Is that the full grasp Bryce?

PM11:25am

Our Global Equity Strategist is relatively more constructive on H1 than H2 2017.

BE11:25am

"Sufficient" is the word I'd use, in terms of grasp.

11:26 am
BE11:26am

BE11:27am

We Raise Our Mid-year Target on the S&P 500 to 2,350 from 2,200 and Introduce an End-17 Target of 2,300: What are the positives? (i) Currently investors are overweight deflation hedges (i.e. bonds) relative to inflation hedges (equities) when policy makers are moving away from NIRP towards fiscal stimulus, and inflation expectations are set to continue rising; (ii) Earnings revisions are near a five-year high, and we foresee a rebound in US earnings; (iii) there is a still reasonably elevated equity risk premium; (iv) excess liquidity remains supportive; and (v) economic momentum is set to rise, which isn’t discounted by bond to equity returns.
However, we see a down market in H2 2017, hence our year-end 2017 target of 2,300. The second half challenges include the potential negative impact of US bond yields above 3% (3% being the Credit Suisse view for end-2017), the growing pricing power of US labor squeezing profit margins, and the risk of China refocusing on reform rather than pro-growth policies. We continue to prefer equities to both bonds and gold.
The macro backdrop is one of a modest acceleration in global GDP growth, with upside risks to the Credit Suisse view of 3.0% global GDP growth in 2017.
Bond Yields to Rise Further: The combination of accelerating growth, rising inflation, and a change in the policy conversation toward fiscal rather than monetary stimulus present significant challenges to bond prices, in our view. Adding to this, the election of Donald Trump adds an additional issuance challenge, with his fiscal plans costing $5.3trn (and with the Fed also owning $2.5trn worth of debt it may choose to unwind). The Credit Suisse house view is for the US 10-year Treasury yield to end 2017 at 3%; we would agree (and think the bond yield could rise toward 1% over the same period), but our judgement would be that the risks lie, if anything, to the upside.

BE11:27am

Continental Europe: Add to Overweight: Europe is now our biggest overweight (along with Japan) for the following reasons: (i) European equities have lagged the European recovery implying a c.20% outperformance; (ii) Fund flows: 39 weeks of outflows in 2016 leave sentiment extremely depressed; (iii) European political risk is overstated; (iv) A play on global growth and rising yields; (v) European equities are cheap (22% discount to US on 12m fwd P/E), (vi) We expect the euro to weaken (10% off the euro adds 6pp to EPS growth and 1.1pp on nominal GDP growth).
Japan: Remain Overweight: Offers an attractive combination of macro supports and bottom-up positives. From the macro side, it is a quintuple play on rising global growth and US bond yields and bottom-up positives include valuation, fund flows, signs of corporate change and strong domestic momentum.
GEM: Reduce Overweight: The macro backdrop is less favorable: the dollar, TIPS yield, oil price and perceptions of China were uniquely supportive through first three quarters of 2016, but now appear very much less so as the USD and DM yields rise. We remain positive given still attractive valuations of both FX and equities and improving relative profitability. External risks have also reduced as current accounts deficits have declined in size.
US: Remain Underweight: The most defensive of global markets, which typically underperforms if global growth and US bond yields rise. It is also expensive, with margins well above average levels. Our increased caution on growth as a style is also a challenge for US equities.

BE11:35am

PM11:35am

11:35 am
BE11:35am

BE11:36am

Note also that the Sanofi deal looks complicated.

BE11:36am

Potential of including a contingent value right

11:36 am
BE11:36am

Paying out depending on pipeline success.

PM11:36am

goodness

BE11:36am

Largely around ponesimod, which is an MS treatment in PhIII.

11:36 am
PM11:36am

That's a worrying development for anyone trying to sell drug companies

BE11:37am

Actelion, one could argue, isn't like a normal drug company though.

BE11:37am

It's one of the few to be run by scientists rather than accountants.

11:37 am
BE11:37am

Let me chuck some Barclays into this information vacuum.

BE11:37am

Deal math: We note that an outright purchase of Actelion using cash/debt and at the presumed price of $275/sh leads to 6-11% earnings accretion – if you were to assume anywhere between CHF0-560m of deal synergies (Actelion’s R&D cost base stands at around CHF560m). Although we think it is likely the overlap of specific pipeline assets with Sanofi’s business (multiple sclerosis, Fabry Disease) makes a complete restructuring of R&D unlikely. We also note that Actelion does not partake in its own manufacturing (outsourced to several suppliers) and that the SG&A infrastructure is the foundation for the company’s strong relationships and PAH success. (This deal math is using Bloomberg consensus estimates for Sanofi and our published numbers for Actelion).

BE11:38am

(@Dub: because of the contingent value right proposal, chief.)

11:38 am
BE11:38am

Our thoughts on ATLN as a company: We currently value the business at CHF145/sh. We have been cautious on Actelion shares through 2016 as we fear over-confidence by the market on the rapid launch of Uptravi (we have similar peak sales projections but a slower ramp there) and the lack of Opsumit vulnerability to Letairis generics. (see our recent note: Actelion: Still looking for a crystal ball, 1 Nov 2016) Our fair value of CHF145 prices in little pipeline success and leaves our core EPS forecasts 1% below recently published Vara consensus estimates in 2017 and 2018.

BE11:38am

In order to become more positive we are looking for the following:

(1) Uptravi: quarterly revenue numbers imply new patients per quarter in the US region is softening around c500 for the time being (we have always believed 2H 16- FY17 would remain gradual as a pickup from here relies on penetration into “slow-adopting” prostacyclin prescribers – 70% of total. Our revised estimate of c600 new patients per quarter worldwide in 2017 and c700 in 2018 leads to product revenues of CHF496m and CHF696m, respectively. We note that every incremental 400 patients in the US (c100 per quarter) equates to CHF37m of revenues.

(2) Opsumit: Company comments at Q3 results that Opsumit and competitor Letairis are splitting new patient share 50/50 reinforced our view that the 2018 price/volume dynamics for Opsumit may be at risk. Our revised targets assume Opsumit loses 20% of its worldwide new patients by 2017, 35% by 2018 and 50% by 2019. With the assumption of worldwide pricing pressure (specifically an 11% decrease in the Opsumit US net price for 2017-20) this leads to our base case revenue numbers of CHF1.07bn and CHF1.2bn in 2017 and 2018, respectively. Flat pricing for Opsumit in the US would add 5-9% to our midterm EPS and CHF10/sh to valuation, but we see this as unlikely given the more disciplined US pricing landscape.

(3) Pipeline: At this point we only include CHF115m peak sales for the pipeline (cadazolid) although our DCF valuation does include a terminal value, implying that R&D investment is met with a level of success and can sustain the company’s return on capital. What could move the needle? We await the read out of the phase III OPTIMUM study (ponesimod versus Tecfidera in relapsing multiple sclerosis – currently recruiting) which could add pipeline value – although differentiation is needed in the crowded multiple sclerosis class.

BE11:41am

Actelion's a weird one. The rumour's run so long that much of the shareholder base would seem to be diametrically opposed to the company founders, who one could argue are its biggest source of intangible value that might produce a bid capable of pleasing that shareholder base.

11:41 am
BE11:41am

I tired myself out typing that. Let's move on.

undefined
PM11:41am

I thought you'd be typing fit with me being away

11:41 am
PM11:41am

Didnt want to interrupt

BE11:42am

Honeywell warning on the tape while we were looking elsewhere.

BE11:42am

*HONEYWELL SEES 2017 EPS $6.85-$7.10, EST. $7.09

11:42 am
BE11:42am

That's a bad sign. Folk not buying thermostats.

BE11:43am

Readthrough for .......... dunno. Melrose?

BE11:44am

Otherwise, we have Micro Focus leading us lower.

11:44 am
BE11:44am

UBS .........

BE11:44am

Notwithstanding H1's good results and a $400m planned Return of Value, we see the upside for the shares as limited now. We see several risks in 2017: (1) HPE has to execute a significant ($700m) carve-out process on its software assets to make them ready to pass-on to MCRO. There are risks of delays to the deal's closing (due in August 2017) and of disruption to sales execution within HPE Software before or around closing. We note that Micro Focus is due to take on the assets at the start of HPE Software's fiscal Q4 which last year accounted for nearly 40% of full year licence sales and profits. (2) MCRO's cash flow, meanwhile, is likely to show the effects of significant legal and advisory fees related to the deal ahead of its closing, and restructuring commitments are likely to be a feature thereafter; (3) There are flow-back risks around the deal which will see HPE shareholders own half the combined company on closing.

BE11:45am

H1 17 results showed pleasing momentum on the cost front; something that should reassure ahead of the HPE Software transaction closing next year. Pro forma EBITDA was up $18m y/y with underlying revenue growth driving $4m of this, a reduced Deferred Income haircut a further $4m, and lower costs $10m. Management revealed that since acquiring TAG two years ago, headcount (ex-SUSE) has fallen 15% and the number of properties used by around a third to less than 100.

11:45 am
BE11:45am

Our estimates change little on an underlying basis, although we now embed a Deferred Income haircut to HPE Software, as management indicated this would be applied. Allowing for the equity issuance and additional debt to be taken on, Micro Focus has a pro forma EV today of $17bn. Its long-term ambition is a $2bn EBITDA run-rate, but it will take time (and good execution) - to get there.

BE11:45am

Our 2350p price target is based on a blend of 2021E EV/EBITDA (SUSE), EV/NOPAT (core) and 2021E equity FCF analysis, discounted back to today. We downgrade to Neutral.

BE11:46am

Cobol! Growth industry!

11:45 am
undefined
BE11:46am

Heinepunch mentioned, though not a lot to add really.

BE11:46am

Puncheken.

11:46 am
BE11:46am

Whatever.

Punch Taverns PLC (PUB:LSE): Last: 190.50, down 0.5 (-0.26%), High: 192.50, Low: 190.00, Volume: 3.67m
PM11:47am

Whats the story here?

11:47 am
PM11:47am

Missed this

BE11:47am

Heineken rescuing Punch from what looked like the eternal purgatory of twin securitisation structures.

PM11:48am

goodness

11:48 am
BE11:48am

The equity was only ever a stub, of course.

BE11:48am

Here's Citi to explain the logic from Heineken's perspective.

BE11:49am

The news - Heineken‎ has reached an agreement to take over (with co-bidder Patron Capital) Punch Tavern, one of the largest UK pub operators. In summary, Heineken will take about 1,900 pubs for £305m + about £900m debt, equating to a multiple of about 11x EV/EBITDA (FY16). The deal is expected to complete in 1H17, subject to Punch shareholder approval and regulatory review.

11:49 am
BE11:49am

Strengthens Heineken's UK position - The UK is Heineken's #4 market by profit on our estimates, contributing ~7-8% of group EBIT (or even ‎#3 today, given the sharp fall in profit in Nigeria). Heineken has a market share of around 20% in the UK, similar in the on-trade and off-trade. It already owns c1,050 pubs, through its Star Pubs division, which provide a stable stream of rental income in addition to good margins on the beer supplied to the pubs, we believe. Punch will strengthen Heineken's position in the on-trade, important particularly in light of the more challenging grocery environment. With Punch, Heineken's pub estate will increase to just fewer than 3,000, making it the UK's 3rd largest pub group.

BE11:50am

I'd never really released that Heineken had pubs, though in retrospect it's obvious given the beer tie.

BE11:50am

Low single digit EPS accretion - Assuming cost of financing of 3% on the equity and net profit for the business Heineken is acquiring of just over €30m, we estimate‎ potential EPS accretion of about 1.5% (Heineken says the deal will be EPS enhancing in year 1). This is before (likely) benefits from integrating the pubs into Heineken's existing UK business, including supplying Heineken's products to the new pubs. ‎The timing of the deal seems right given the GBP weakness.
Headroom for other potential medium-size deals - Punch takes Heineken's Net Debt/Ebitda (2016 PF) to ~2.6x on our estimates (vs 2.4x, on our current forecasts). While Heineken targets Net debt/Ebitda below 2.5x, we believe it would be comfortable to go to 3x or a bit more for strategic M&A. In our recent deep-dive report on Heineken’s M&A (see link on page 2), we suggested that on a 12 months view it is possible that Heineken could acquire Kirin's beer assets in Brazil or it could take majority control of UBL. These deals would add about 0.45x and 0.15-0.4x respectively to Heineken's Net debt/Ebitda, based on assumptions we outlined in the report. In other words, we believe the Punch deal would leave enough balance sheet headroom to potentially do both, just about, should the opportunity present itself.

11:50 am
BE11:50am

More balance EM-DMs? - Over the past few years Heineken has transformed its business, ‎re-weighting the baricentre towards EMs. However with increased macro and FX volatility in EMs, Heineken (and other FMCGs) is also probably reappraising the benefits of less "growthy", but more stable DMs. Committing over £1bn to the UK is proof of that, in our view.

BE11:51am

More interestingly, or at least more presciently ...

BE11:51am

.... Canaccord upgrading Enterprise Inns on the back of the Punch bid.

11:51 am
PM11:52am

Isnt this all a bit back to the future? As in tied pub estates

BE11:53am

Yes ...... I'll expect a lot of stuff in the Sundays about the future of the pub sector and shrinking estates and wet-led sales and all that junk, because Sunday hacks seem to love these themes.

PM11:53am

Yeah, good for readership stats

11:53 am
BE11:53am

Here's Canaccord's thinking.

BE11:53am

We are upgrading our recommendation for Enterprise Inns to BUY from Hold and increasing our target price to 150p from 115p. The contested bid for Punch Taverns resulting in an agreed offer 40% above the undisturbed share price is a reminder of the latent value of the asset-intense pubcos in general and Enterprise Inns in particular. The Punch bid may have been the catalyst for our reappraisal but it is not the sole reason. Enterprise Inns is now making good progress versus its strategic plan to transform the company's business model against a known regulatory environment. This, in turn, should deliver an improving quality cashflow which will be channelled into paying down debt and share buy-backs, assuming no change to Enterprise's EV; this should act as a powerful driver for the share price and push it towards 200p by 2020.

BE11:53am

Enterprise's market capitalisation of £572m is just 25% of its £2.8bn EV so small changes can result in large moves in the share price. Over the next four years Enterprise is scheduled to pay off c£336m of Unique bond debt. It is also planning to buy back c.£25m of shares pa, or c£100m from the commencement of the programme through 2020, equivalent to 14% of the market capitalisation. This can be financed out of cashflow with the £300m of property outside the securitisations providing the safety cushion should circumstances change. To date, ETI has bought back £18m (17m of shares at an average price of 94p) of the planned £25m. We expect ETI to renew its share buy-back permission at the February AGM. In November, Enterprise repurchased £250m of the £350m corporate bonds due 2018, financed by a new £250m bond, due February 2022, at a coupon of 6.375%. The refinancing was expensive in our view as it paid 111.0% of the principal, representing a cash payment of £27.5m but it reduces a potential 'negative' to future share price performance.
Our concern over the execution risk of adapting the business model to the new regulatory environment (enshrined in the Small Business, Enterprise and Employment Act which came into effect on 21 July 2016) is falling in line with Enterprise's progress. At end FY16, it had delivered 105 managed houses and 291 free-of-tie deals as promised. Encouragingly, the threat to its business model from the Market Rent Option (MRO) is also proving to be less of a worry. Since the new legislation was enacted there have been 285 trigger events, of which 94 have requested a MRO quote, none of which has resulted in a MRO compliant agreement. In 2017 there are c600 events that may trigger a request for a MRO quote.

11:53 am
BE11:53am

Our new 150p target price represents a staging post towards 2020. It also reflects the execution risk explicit in delivery of the plan. It is equivalent to a PE of 8.2x, EV/EBITDA of 10x and FCF yield of 5.2% for FY17E falling to 7.7x, 9.6x and 9.8% for FY18E. Our TP is underpinned by a NAV of 290p/share for FY17E.

PM11:54am

hmm -- trading at less than half book value

BE11:55am

Have a google around the blogs for Enterprise Inns, incidentally. The evidence from that unscientific method hints that they seem to annoy landlords.

11:55 am
BE11:55am

Dunno whether that's just because landlords spend a lot of their time annoyed though.
